content.description: Hands & thin hands bring you to a short ringlock section. Clip a seemingly unnecessary bolt and continue on. Gain a bulge & move upwards into a wide section, enjoying face features as you go. Clip another (more reasonable) bolt and solve one last sandy wide pod before exiting to a rest. Finish up through a beautiful section of splitter to the chains.
content.location: Obvious left facing dihedral climbers right of "Rick James" and left of all the other routes on Jolly Green Giant.

content.description: Start at solution pockets left of the corner. The first bolt is located inside one of the larger pockets. Surmount the corner, then ascend 3 bolts up the face (crux). Lower from chains.
content.protection: 4 glue in bolts to a 3-bolt anchor station.
content.location:
Located near the far right hand side (if looking at the wall from the road) of the Jolly Green Giant.

Set this route up for toprope by scrambling up to the anchors from the right-hand side of the ridge.

content.description: Start at the bottom of the seam, work you way up to the bulge/roof that splits the slab, at the lip pull some yoga moves and get your feet up and over, it keeps coming at you after this too, very continuous to the 2 bolt anchor.
content.protection: 4"x 1/2" rawls, are the fixed anchors. QD's
content.location: If you are passing the petroglyphs, going to Pine Canyon, Dylan wall, etc., there is a pull out/camping area IMMEDIATELY on your left after you pass the restroom/tourist/petroglyph area. As you pull in the big circle note that straight ahead is a black slab with a mini-roof splitting the entire slab. This was the only route as of 10/07

content.description:
P1) Start at a short but beautiful finger crack in a corner, located near several large boulders (crux). Mantel onto a ledge at the top of the crack, then move right up the wide crack. Chimney between the main wall on your left and the brown sugar on your right. Stem across to the left wall and clip a glue-in bolt for protection before launching onto the slab. Continue up the slab past another glue-in to a chain anchor.

A slightly easier start is to move left 10 feet and lieback the big flake before you mantel onto the block above the finger crack.

P2) Move from the belay station to the big ledge below pitch two. Mantel onto a small shelf right off the ledge, then clip a glue-in. Move right into the shallow corner, then back left onto the slab. Follow the slab for three more glue-ins to a three bolt belay station.

This is a really easy route by San Rafael standards, but it is super fun and well protected. It should find appeal for those not adept to the pain and suffering of small splitters and the self flagellation of chimneys and off widths.
content.protection: Finger sized cam for the crux finger crack. One or two large cams (size 5-6) are nice for the wide crack. The rest of the route is all protected by wave-bolt glue-in anchors.
content.location:
If you are looking at the formation from the road, the route stats about 100' right of the tallest part of the formation, down in the shorter blocks and domes.  It ascends a weakness in the cliff system. An obvious finger splitter formed by a triangle block marks the start fo the route.

The best descent: from the anchors on the second pitch (summit ridge), walk south-east (down canyon) to where the cliff band meets the ground.
